anical Integrity - manufacturer recommended maintenance procedures, schedules, and documentation 
-	Management of Change - documentation and tracking of changes that effect the process involving the regulated chemical 
-	Pre-Startup Review - prior to the startup of a new regulated process or major changes to the existing process, a review will be conducted, as required by PSM and RMP regulations 
-	Compliance Audits - documentation of triennial audits of the covered process 
-	Incident Investigation - documentation and investigation procedures for determining and mitigating releases 
-	Employee Participation - documentation and statement of C&S commitment to providing a safe and open work place 
-	Hot Work Permit - procedures for documenting and safely performing work on or near process equipment during normal operations 
-	Contractors - policy for contractors and outside vendors that work on or near the regulated process 
These elements are continually updated and reviewed through the Management System at the Facility. The Management System includes planning, organizing, implementing, and controlling different aspects of the plan. 
Five Year Accident History 
There have been no significant releases of ammonia at the Facility in the last five years (January 2023 - January 2018) of ammonia that exceeded the Federal Reportable Quantity of 100 pounds. In addition, there have been no injuries resulting from an ammonia release. 
Emergency Response Program 
C&S has developed an Ammonia Emergency Action Plan which includes but is not limited to the following: - emergency response and evacuation procedures - safety and health considerations - notification procedures - local emergency response agencies - environmental offsite consequences 
Planned Changes 
Changes determined by the most recent PHA and considerations made during the development of this plan will be conducted in a timely manner. 
Updates 
The RMP for the Facility will be updated at least every five years, and

y in the event of a release, it provides the local responding agencies with a maximum possible impact in the event of an accidental release. In considering these releases, the most pessimistic meteorological conditions were used. Passive mitigation measures were taken into account when considering these release scenarios. 
Alternative Release Scenarios 
Alternative scenarios were developed to assess what potential impact may occur in the event of a release that is more likely to occur than the worst-case scenarios for each of the regulated chemicals. Several possible release scenarios were considered, and the scenarios with the greatest offsite impact were chosen. In considering the alternative release scenario, the default meteorological conditions for alternative scenarios were used in RMP*Comp. These scenarios represent a more realistic release, and have a downwind distance and impact considerably smaller than the worst-case scenario. No passive or active mitigation measures were taken into account when considering these release scenarios. 
General Accidental Release Prevention Programs and Prevention Steps 
As part of the implementation of the RMP, elements of the prevention programs have been developed to manage process safety issues associated with the facility. Each of the program elements has been developed according to OSHA and EPA regulations in order to ensure safe operating practices and conditions at the C&S facility. Elements of Prevention Program 3 include the following: 
-	Process Safety Information - information regarding the hazards of anhydrous ammonia, process description, and equipment properties 
-	Process Hazard Analysis - a detailed review of the process, and recommendations to improve the safety of the systems at the Facility 
-	Operating Procedures - procedures designed to comply with regulations and provide safe practices for the systems at the Facility 
-	Training - procedures and logs for personnel training on the covered process 
-	Mech

RMP Executive Summary 
This summary is presented for the five year RMP update. The ammonia refrigeration system provides cooling for coolers,freezer, high-pressure glycol chiller and dock areas and uses a charge of 22,404 pounds of ammonia.  
Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies 
C&S Wholesale Services, Inc. (C&S) is committed to the safety of its employees and neighbors and operates the Facility as a responsible member of the community. Personnel are encouraged to continually identify methods and procedures to reduce the use of and risks associated with hazardous chemicals. This process includes protecting the community, environment, and Facility personnel by implementing technology and procedures designed to reduce the impact of any potential release of toxic chemicals. This commitment to safety is documented in the policy and compliance manuals for the Facility, which are available to all employees. 
Regulated Substance 
C&S utilizes anhydrous ammonia within a refrigeration system at the Facility. The facility uses approximately 22,404 pounds of anhydrous ammonia. 
Off-site Release Scenarios 
C&S has conducted an OCA based on the EPA document titled RMP Offsite Consequence Analysis Guidelines, and used the EPA's RMP*Comp Version 1.07 to estimate the distance traveled to a toxic endpoint defined by the EPA regulation. This data were then used to estimate the potential impact caused by a release from each of the regulated substances. At the time of the hazard assessment update the 2020 census data was not in Marplot or the CAPS tool. The population numbers in this update therefore are still based on 2010 census. I contacted Marplot and they said they were not sure when the data would be updated.
Worst-Case Release Scenarios
